abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Eighth (Diesel) Power
            Project for Sri Lanka was satisfactory. The project achieved
            its technical objectives, its impact has been significant,
            sustainability is likely, and both the Bank and Borrower
            performed satisfactorily. Several lessons can be learned
            from this project. First, the CEB (Ceylon Electricity Board)
            should assess the feasibility of installing radiator cooling
            in anticipation of restricted access to unpolluted and
            sufficient sources of natural cooling water. Second, the
            timely amendment of the performance bond clause of the
            contract would have avoided the accrual of the large amount
            of retention monies and allowed the remaining funds in the
            loan account to be largely disbursed. Third, running the
            diesels sparingly has reduced the possibility of overcoming
            teething problems before the plant is required to run at a
            high load factor and has limited training opportunities,
            which will increase the risk factor in future operation at
            high load. Fourth, reporting on project execution and
            accounting was inadequate and needs to be improved. Fifth,
            the possibility of future problems stemming from the use of
            potable water for cooling should have been anticipated and
            alternatives explored. Lastly, the CEB should implement a
            program to recruit and retain experienced staff.
